{{Infobox building | name = St James House, Monmouth | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_names = | alternate_names = | status = | image = St. James House.JPG | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = St James House at [[St James Square, Monmouth|St James Square]]
and [[Whitecross Street, Monmouth|Whitecross Street]] | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = | address = 10 St James Square
10 Whitecross Street | location_town = [[Monmouth]] | location_country = [[Wales]] | coordinates = {{Coord|51.813235|-2.711477|display=inline,title}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = | completion_date = | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | height = | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | observatory = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | elevator_count = | main_contractor = | architect = | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | designations = [[Grade II Listed]] | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | parking = | url = | embedded = | references = }} '''St James House''' is a [[grade II listed]] building in [[Monmouth]], [[Monmouthshire]], [[Wales]]. It is in the historic [[St James Square, Monmouth|St James Square]] neighbourhood, within the [[Monmouth Town Walls and Defences|Medieval town walls]]. While the house currently has an attractive, 18th-century facade, it originated as a [[burgage]] tenement. In addition, behind the house, evidence of a kiln has been unearthed, with both [[Medieval]] and [[Post-medieval archaeology|Post-medieval]] pottery. In 2010, archaeological excavation in the square revealed the first evidence of [[Monmouth in the Mesolithic period|Mesolithic human settlement in Monmouth]]. Recent residents of St James House have included boarding students from [[Monmouth School]]. ==Neighbourhood and location== [[File:St James' Square, Monmouth - geograph.org.uk - 308231.jpg|thumb|240px|right|View from southwest side of [[St James Square, Monmouth|St James Square]] with [[Monmouth War Memorial]], installed 1921, and [[The Indian Bean Tree, St James' Square, Monmouth|Indian Bean Tree]], planted c. 1900 and the [[Old Nag's Head, Monmouth|Old Nag's Head]] beyond.]] [[File:Whitecross Street, Monmouth - geograph.org.uk - 648859.jpg|thumb|240px|right|[[33 Whitecross Street, Monmouth|33 Whitecross Street]] (far left), St James House (right), and [[The Rolls Hall, Monmouth|Public Library]] (centre)]] [[File:Old map of Monmouth, Wales.jpg|thumb|240px|right|1610 map of [[Monmouth]] by [[John Speed]] with [[Monmouth Town Walls and Defences|East Gate (Dixton Gate)]] marked M, and cross]] "There are some lovely spots in the town centre, none prettier than St James's Square, with its old war memorial in the shadow of a romantic-looking tree." This is the description of St James Square ''(pictured)'' in Monmouth, Wales that appeared in ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' of 25 February 2006.{{cite news|title=City spotlight: Monmouth|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/cities/3347952/City-spotlight-Monmouth.html|accessdate=26 May 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=25 Feb 2006|author=Max Davidson}} The war memorial mentioned is the [[Monmouth War Memorial]] that was installed in the square in 1921 and was the work of sculptor W. Clarke of [[Llandaff]].{{cite book|title=Gwent/Monmouthshire|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn= 9780300096309|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=knRf4U60QjcC&pg=PA408&lpg=PA408&dq=Old+Nag's+Head+tower+in+Monmouth&source=bl&ots=1zMDTKNOco&sig=yTn_DWXgO7q-kM-HUdPTH0cLZOY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=TeOqT-yRGYag8QSqqMmyBg&ved=0CFwQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false|author=John Newman|edition=illustrated|accessdate=26 May 2012|page=408|date=11 March 2000}} The "romantic-looking tree" is a reference to the [[Catalpa bignonioides|Catalpa]] or [[The Indian Bean Tree, St James' Square, Monmouth|Indian Bean Tree]] that was planted on the square in about 1900.{{cite web|title=Council v Council in Catalpa Tree Clash|url=http://www.hackersons.co.uk/monmouth/Features/feature4.php|work=hackersons.co.uk|publisher=Monmouth Community|accessdate=26 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140408224928/http://www.hackersons.co.uk/monmouth/Features/feature4.php|archivedate=8 April 2014|df=}} St James House ''(pictured)'' is located at the eastern end of [[Whitecross Street, Monmouth|Whitecross Street]], where it terminates at the [[roundabout]] encircling the triangular St James Square. The building is positioned on the north side of the square, across from [[33 Whitecross Street, Monmouth|33 Whitecross Street]] ''(pictured)'', the site of archaeological excavation in 2009.{{cite web|title=monmouthshire sir fynwy|url=http://idox.monmouthshire.gov.uk/WAM/findCaseFile.do?address=33+Whitecross+Street&appType=Planning&action3=Search|work=idox.monmouthshire.gov.uk|publisher=Monmouthshire County Council|accessdate=26 May 2012}} St James House lies within the Medieval town walls which were built around 1300.{{cite web|title=Monnow Bridge|url=http://www.cofiadurcahcymru.org.uk/arch/query/page.php?watprn=GGAT01256g&dbname=ggat&tbname=core|work=cofiadurcahcymru.org.uk|publisher=The Glamorgan-Gwent Archaeological Trust Historic Environment Record|accessdate=26 May 2012}}{{cite web|title=Virtual Map of Monmouth|url=http://www.monmouth.org.uk/index.php/visitors/geography/virtual-monmouth-map.html|work=monmouth.org.uk|publisher=The Monmouth Website|accessdate=26 May 2012}} On the 1610 map of Monmouth ''(pictured below)'' by [[cartographer]] [[John Speed]], the area which served as the site for St James House is depicted adjacent to the label for the [[Monmouth Town Walls and Defences|East Gate (Dixton Gate)]]. However, as discussed by author William Meyler Warlow, the square, as well as the road south of it, including the future [[St James Street, Monmouth|St James Street]] and Almshouse Street, were all considered to be part of Whitecross Street during the early 17th century. A white cross, which gave its name to the street, stood in the square ''(see map)''.{{cite book|title=A history of the charities of William Jones (founder of the "Golden lectureship" in London), at Monmouth & Newland|year=1899|publisher=W. Bennett|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iNo8l9bYMHkC&pg=PA37&lpg=PA37&dq=Nailer's+Lane,+Monmouth,+drawbridge&source=bl&ots=pELbungl8I&sig=vxi-SJv7huTcTEA0eVv6TH9GHU0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=iLS6T9ycE4SksQL70qGLDA&ved=0CF4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Nailer's%20Lane%2C%20Monmouth%2C%20drawbridge&f=false|author=William Meyler Warlow|accessdate=26 May 2012|pages=}} As is the case with some other houses on the eastern leg of Whitecross Street, St James House has had two addresses: 10 St James Square and 10 Whitecross Street. ==Design and burgage history== St James House was grade II listed on 27 June 1952.{{cite web|title=St. James's House, Monmouth|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-2324-st-james-s-house-monmouth|work=britishlistedbuildings.co.uk|publisher=British Listed Buildings|accessdate=26 May 2012}} The [[listed building]] has an 18th-century facade with a three-storey, five-bay elevation. The exterior is red brick, highlighted by light-colored, raised stone [[Quoin (architecture)|quoins]] which serve as the [[cornerstones]] of the walls, contrasting with the brick.{{cite web|title=St. James Square, 10, Monmouth; St. James House|url=http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/20782/details/ST.+JAMES+SQUARE%2C+10%2C+MONMOUTH%3BST.+JAMES+HOUSE/|work=coflein.gov.uk|publisher=Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales|accessdate=26 May 2012}} Decorative [[Keystone (architecture)|keystones]] of similar material are atop all of the windows except one, which is lugged and scrolled. The bays on the ground and first floors are rectangular, while those on the uppermost floor are square. The exception is the tall, centre window on the first floor which is round-headed. The centrally-positioned entrance features a wood [[portico]] supported by [[Doric order|Doric]] columns. A [[fanlight]] is present above the door. The roof is flared and [[Hip roof|hipped]]. The interior has a small amount of 17th-century plasterwork. St James House is considered to be a good representation of the [[burgage]] tenements that were common during Medieval times ''(link to glossary below)''. Its origins as a burgage are most evident at the rear of the property. The current, 18th-century facade was a later addition.{{cite web|title=Walking in Monmouth, Monmouthshire and The Wye Valley|url=http://www.monmouth.org.uk/index.php/leisure/walking/63-walking-monmouth.html|work=monmouth.org.uk|publisher=The Monmouth Website|accessdate=26 May 2012}} Burgage tenements were rental properties that were often long and narrow plots of land, particularly in towns where frontage property along a street was at a premium.{{cite web|title=Wiltshire Community History|url=http://history.wiltshire.gov.uk/community/getfaq.php?id=216|work=history.wiltshire.gov.uk|publisher=Wiltshire Council|accessdate=26 May 2012}} The [[gable]] (narrow) end of a house on a burgage plot usually faced the street. The classical style was in vogue during the 18th century, the consequence of which was that many burgage houses received new brick facades.{{cite web|title=Historic towns and built form|url=http://www.hertslink.org/buildingfutures/designs/16950385/16954312/|work=hertslink.org|publisher=Hertfordshire – Building Futures|accessdate=26 May 2012}} Such was the case with St James House. ==Archaeology== Important archaeological finds have been excavated both at St James House and its neighbourhood. Behind St James House, evidence of a Post-medieval [[pottery]] kiln has been unearthed. The kiln at St James House produced Welsh Borderland ceramics of the A7d type. Other Monmouthshire 17th-century kilns which produced this pottery included [[Abergavenny]] and Trefaldu at [[Cwmcarvan]]. A few sources of A7d pottery have been located outside of Monmouthshire as well, including [[Herefordshire]].{{cite web|title=17th century kilns (post-medieval Welsh Borderland wares)|url=http://www.woolhopeclub.org.uk/PotteryFabricA7d.html|work=woolhopeclub.org.uk|publisher=Woolhope Naturalists' Field Club, Herefordshire|accessdate=26 May 2012}} In addition, a base [[sherd]] of Spanish ware excavated by Socket in 1956 at St James House was found to be Medieval, of the early 15th century.{{cite web|title=The Medieval Ceramics|url=http://www.newport.gov.uk/stellent/groups/public/documents/planningdocument/cont621999.pdf|work=newport.gov.uk|publisher=Newport|accessdate=26 May 2012}} On 8 November 2010, the ''[[BBC News]]'' reported that during the course of gas main replacement work at St James Square and Wyebridge Street, [[Mesolithic]] era artefacts, including [[Stone tool|flints]], were excavated ''(link to photograph of flints below)''.{{cite news|title=Items found in Monmouth shed light on Mesolithic man|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-11710978|accessdate=27 May 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=8 November 2010}} An article by Sion Morgan of the ''[[Western Mail (Wales)|Western Mail]]'' which also ran on 8 Nov 2010 in ''[[Wales Online]]'' suggested that similar artefacts were found in St James Street as well.{{cite news|title=Monmouth’s meeting the ancestors from more than 10,000 years ago|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2010/11/08/monmouth-s-meeting-the-ancestors-from-more-than-10-000-years-ago-91466-27617554/|accessdate=27 May 2012|newspaper=Wales Online|date=8 Nov 2010|author=Sion Morgan}} This represented the first discovery of Mesolithic human settlement in Monmouth. ==Residents of St James House== In 1891, Chippenham House, a grade II listed building at 102 [[Monnow Street]], was home to surgeon Thomas Gilbert Prosser (1856–1932), a native of Monmouth.{{cite web|last=Prosser|first=Thomas G|title=1891 Wales Census|work=ancestry.com|publisher=Census Returns of England and Wales, 1891. The National Archives of the UK (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=28 May 2012}}{{cite web|title=Chippenham House, Monmouth|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-2295-chippenham-house-monmouth/comments|work=britishlistedbuildings.co.uk|publisher=British Listed Buildings|accessdate=27 May 2012}} However, the doctor lived at St James House on Whitecross Street in 1901 and 1911.{{cite web|last=Prosser|first=Thomas G|title=1901 Wales Census|work=ancestry.com|publisher=Census Returns of England and Wales, 1901. The National Archives of the UK (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=28 May 2012}}{{cite web|last=Prosser|first=Thomas Gilbert|title=1911 Wales Census|work=ancestry.com|publisher=Census Returns of England and Wales, 1911. The National Archives of the UK (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=28 May 2012}} In [[Kelly's Directory]] of Monmouthshire 1901, Part 2, he is listed as both a county and borough magistrate.{{cite web|title=Kelly's Directory of Monmouthshire 1901 – Monmouth|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~familyalbum/kmon2.htm|work=freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com|publisher=hosted by rootsweb|accessdate=28 May 2012}} In Part 3 of the directory, he is listed as a medical officer at the [[The Dispensary, Monmouth|Hospital & Dispensary]].{{cite web|title=Kelly's Directory of Monmouthshire 1901 – Monmouth|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~familyalbum/kmon3.htm|work=freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com|publisher=hosted by roots web|accessdate=28 May 2012}} Prosser, a member of the [[Royal College of Surgeons]], died on 5 Nov 1932 in Monmouth.{{cite news|url=http://www.edinburgh-gazette.co.uk/issues/13559/pages/322/page.pdf|title=The Edinburgh Gazette|accessdate=28 May 2012|newspaper=The Edinburgh Gazette|date=3 February 1920|page=322}}{{cite web|last=Prosser|first=Thomas Gilbert|title=England & Wales, National Probate Calendar (Index of Wills and Administrations), 1858–1966|work=ancestry.com|publisher=Principal Probate Registry. Calendar of the Grants of Probate and Letters of Administration made in the Probate Registries of the High Court of Justice in England (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=28 May 2012}} William Humphrey Williams (1880–1948), licensed by the [[Royal College of Physicians]] and a member of the Royal College of Surgeons, followed in the footsteps of Prosser, with regard to both profession and residence.{{cite book|title=Burke's Peerage – Baronetage & Knightage|year=2004|publisher=Burke's Peerage and Gentry|url=http://www.exacteditions.com/exact/search.do?term=Nesta+Faith+Green-Price&issueId=6081&titleId=971&sort=0&type=all|edition=107th|accessdate=27 May 2012|page=1650}} He passed his Anatomy and Physiology examinations of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons in July 1903{{cite book|title=Rapport du Comité consultatif: Report of the Advisory committee|year=1903|publisher=Imprimé pour la Société des nations, Harrison & sons|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jJNPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA273&lpg=PA273&dq=William+Humphrey+Williams,+Royal+College+Surgeons&source=bl&ots=PALcvMn0Qk&sig=uJcUDNOLuBbTlOPEWbvKc47ZO1I&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7jTCT9KRHcfM2AX_oux2&ved=0CGUQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=William%20Humphrey%20Williams%2C%20Royal%20College%20Surgeons&f=false|author=International Financial Conference, League of Nations|accessdate=27 May 2012|page=273|chapter=The Lancet}} and, by 1911, he was living at Chippenham House.{{cite web|last=Williams|first=William Humphrey|title=1911 Wales Census|work=ancestry.com|publisher=Census Returns of England and Wales. The National Archives of the UK (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=27 May 2012}}{{cite book|title=Burke's Great War Peerage|year=1914|edition=76th|url=http://www.exacteditions.com/exact/search.do?term=Nesta+Faith+Green-Price&issueId=6081&titleId=971&sort=0&type=all|accessdate=27 May 2012|page=1605}} The following year, on 26 September 1912, he married Nesta Faith Green-Price, daughter of Sir Richard Dansey Green-Price and granddaughter of [[Richard Green-Price|Sir Richard Green-Price]], in [[Radnorshire]].{{cite web|last=Williams|first=William H|title=England & Wales, FreeBMD Marriage Index: 1837–1915|work=ancestry.com|publisher=General Register Office. England and Wales Civil Registration Indexes (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=27 May 2012}}{{cite journal|title=Sir Richard Dansey Green-Price, Bart.|journal=Baily's Magazine of Sports & Pastimes|date=November 1892|volume=58|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8pQbAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA289&lpg=PA289&dq=Sir+Richard+Dansey+Green-Price&source=bl&ots=HgfhwvUvdq&sig=15T0ryEgk3dZ7AANtDKgVgz-FT8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MVbCT_mmIdGFsAKg86TZCQ&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Sir%20Richard%20Dansey%20Green-Price&f=false|accessdate=27 May 2012|pages=289–291}} By 1923, Williams was the Medical Officer of Health for Monmouth and the Williams family resided at St James House. The physician was also medical officer for the Rockfield district and public vaccinator for the Monmouth district. In addition, Williams was medical officer for the Borough Fever Hospital.{{cite web|title=U.K., City and County Directories, 1600s–1900s|work=ancestry.com|publisher=Kelly's Directory of Monmouthshire 1923 (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=13 June 2012}} Williams and his wife lived at St James House prior to Williams' death on 2 March 1948 in Monmouth.{{cite web|title=William Humphrey Williams|url=http://thepeerage.com/p42612.htm|work=thepeerage.com|publisher=The Peerage|accessdate=27 May 2012}}{{cite web|last=Williams|first=William Humphrey|title=England & Wales, National Probate Calendar (Index of Wills and Administrations)|work=ancestry.com|publisher=Principal Probate Registry. Calendar of the Grants of Probate and Letters of Administration made in the Probate Registries of the High Court of Justice in England (as re-printed on Ancestry.com)|accessdate=27 May 2012}} Later, St James House served as a junior boarding house for boys ages ten to thirteen at Monmouth School.{{cite web|title=Key Facts – Boarding Houses|url=http://www.habs-monmouth.org/en/keyfacts|work=habs-monmouth.org|publisher=Haberdashers' Monmouth Schhools|accessdate=28 May 2012}} A J Jones was a housemaster at the St James House location.{{cite web|title=Monmouth School St James House Boarders' Handbook|url=http://www.monmouthschool.org/assets/media/web/0/21509.pdf|work=monmouthschool.org|publisher=Monmouth School|accessdate=28 May 2012}} The Heart Project, a substantial renovation of Monmouth School, was undertaken in early 2011. As part of the first phase of that project, St James House was sold and its boarders were transferred to [[Chapel House, Monmouth|Chapel House]], on the northern segment of [[Monk Street, Monmouth|Monk Street]], in September 2011. The first phase also included redevelopment of [[The Grange, Monmouth|The Grange]] from a prep school to a [[sixth form]] boarding house, which also opened in September 2011. The second phase of the school building project has begun.{{cite web|title=The Heart Project|url=http://www.monmouthschool.org/en/m_heart_project_2012|work=monmouthschool.org|publisher=Monmouth School|accessdate=28 May 2012}} ==See also== * [[Monmouth School]] * [[St James Square, Monmouth]] * [[Whitecross Street, Monmouth]] * [[Monmouth in the Mesolithic period]] * [[Monmouth Town Walls and Defences]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050404115544/http://the-orb.net/encyclop/culture/towns/glossary.html Medieval English Towns – Glossary] * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-11710978 Photograph of Mesolithic flints found in St James Square] * [http://www.monmouthschool.org/en/m_heart_project_2012 Monmouth School – The Heart Project] {{Buildings in Monmouth}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Houses in Monmouth, Wales]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Monmouthshire]] [[Category:Cadw]] [[Category:Grade II listed buildings in Monmouthshire]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Orphan|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox organization | name = Students' Ethnographic Association (SEA) | former name = | bgcolor = | fgcolor = | image = Students'_Ethnographic_Association,_logo.png | image_border = | size = | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = August 1998 [[Minsk]], Belarus | extinction = | type = Non-governmental organization | status = | purpose = | headquarters = 220036, vulica Karła Libkniechta 112, [[Minsk]], [[Belarus]]
phone + 375 17 208 20 90
fax + 375 17 208 44 28 | location = | coords = | region_served = [[Belarus]] | membership = | language = | general = | leader_title = | leader_name = [[Alaksiej Hłuško]] | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = [http://set.ethno.by/ set.ethno.by]
set@ethno.by | remarks = }} '''Students' Ethnographic Association''' (SEA) ([[Belarusian language|Belarusian]]: Студэ́нцкае этнаграфі́чнае тавары́ства (СЭТ)) is a Belarusian non-governmental youth organisation, founded in August 1998. It is recognised by [[UNESCO]] as an expert in the field of [[intangible cultural heritage]].http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/doc/src/ITH-13-8.COM-14.a_-EN.doc The Council of SEA operates in [[Minsk|Miensk]], where the headquarters are situated. The Association also has its branches in [[Hrodna|Horadnia]], [[Viciebsk]] and [[Mahilou|Mahiloŭ]]. == Aims and activities == The organization is focused on preserving and developing the cultural traditions of Belarus, as well as the country's natural and cultural landscape. Its activities include: * organisation of ethnographic expeditions; * organisation of traditional holidays and ceremonies, participation in holidays, which take part in authentic surroundings; * organisation of summer camps, workshops and educational courses on traditional crafts; * learning traditional songs and dances; * organisation of exhibitions and festivals; * publication of folklore materials in printed and electronic forms; * organisation of meetings, lectures, seminars, creation of scientific and educational literature; * organisation of ecological actions, protection of landscapes and architectural monuments; * promotion of traditional culture in medias; * participation in international festivals, holidays and summer schools. === ''Hukańnie viasny'' spring festival === ''Hukańnie viasny'' festival is organised annually in Viazynka and is designed to greet the coming spring.http://belarusdigest.com/story/record-violations-local-elections-freedom-day-rally-crs-awards-belarus-civil-society-digest-17 File:Hukańnie viasny, 2012, Viazynka.jpg|Crafts market, Hukańnie viasny, 2012 == Ethnographic expeditions == The Association organized more than twenty ethnographic expeditions to different regions of Belarus.http://www.slideshare.net/alenacichanczuk/en-set-presentation It has created its own scientific archive and ethnographic collections, composed of some 2,000 hours of audio-visual materials and 50,000 photos.http://belsat.eu/be/wiadomosci/a,16998,pry-unesco-upiershyniu-akredytavali-ghramadskuiu-arghanizatsyiu-z-bielarusi.html {| | * Lepiel-1998 * Uśviaty-1999 * Sianno-2000 * Krupki-2001 * Siebiež-2002 | || | * Haradok-2003 * Barysaŭ-2004 * Lozna-2005 * Ušačy-2006 * Staryja Darohi-2007 | ||| | * Suraž-2007 * Latgalija-2007 * Drybin-2008 * Čašniki-2008 * Kalinkavičy-2009 | |||| | * Sianno-2009 * Śvietłahorsk-2010 * Klimavičy-2010 * Kličaŭ-2011 * Dziatłava-2012 | ||||| | * Dokšycy-2012 * Horki-2013 * Vialejka-2014 * Masty-2014 * Čavusy-2014 |} === Horki-2013 === An ethnographic expedition to [[Horki Raion|Horki district]] [[Mahiloŭ Voblast|Mahiloŭ region]] was organised from 5 to 23 August 2013. During the expedition, a vast collection of audio-visual materials (about 500 songs and its variants) was gathered and local textile and other crafts were analysed. The major part of [[Horki Raion|Horki district]] was covered by the expedition. In addition, a solid analysis of the border area of [[Krasninsky District, Smolensk Oblast|Kraśninski district]] [[Smolensk Oblast|Smalensk region]] (Russia) was carried out. In Russia the work was conducted in cooperation with the culture department of [[Krasninsky District, Smolensk Oblast|Kraśninski district]].http://www.smalensk.org/?p=1006 == Partners == Students' Ethnographic Association collaborates with various scientific, research and educational institutions of Belarus, including the Scientific and Educational Centre of the [[Maxim Tank Belarusian State Pedagogical University|Belarusian State Pedagogical University]], Institute of Art, Ethnography and Folklore of the [[National Academy of Sciences of Belarus]], Belarusian Institute of Problems of Culture, Belarusian State Museum of Folk Architecture and Rural Lifestyle, cultural institutions in Belarusian regions, as well as youth organisations and folk groups from [[Lithuania]], [[Latvia]], [[Poland]], [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Estonia]] and [[Sweden]]. == Honourable members == * [[Zinaida Mažejka]] * [[Rehina Hamzovič]] == External links == * [http://set.ethno.by Official homepage] * [http://by-ethno.livejournal.com LiveJournal] * [http://vk.com/ethno_by VK] * [http://www.facebook.com/set.ethno.by/info Facebook] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Youth organizations based in Belarus]] [[Category:Ethnography]] [[Category:Belarusian folklore]] [[Category:Cultural organizations based in Belarus]]

{{Infobox Journal | title = Studia Etymologica Cracoviensia | cover = | editor = [[Marek Stachowski (linguist)|Marek Stachowski]] | discipline = [[Historical linguistics]] | language = English, French, German | abbreviation = | publisher = [[Cracow University]] | country = Poland | frequency = Annually | history = 1996-present | openaccess = | website = http://www2.filg.uj.edu.pl/ifo/kjasis/sec/ | ISSN = 1427-8219 | eISSN = 2084-3836 | OCLC = 37359425 }} '''''Studia Etymologica Cracoviensia''''' is an annual peer-reviewed [[academic journal]] covering [[historical linguistics]] on languages of Eurasia. The founder and the [[editor-in-chief]] is [[Marek Stachowski (linguist)|Marek Stachowski]]. It was established in 1996 and is published by [[Cracow University]].
The journal is abstracted and indexed in the [[Central and Eastern European Online Library]], the [[Central European Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities]], [[ProQuest]], and [[EBSCO Publishing|EBSCO databases]].
==Contents== The journal prints artiles only in English, German and French languages. The published contributions are mainly original articles. Some volumes contain a small number of reviews, as well as obituaries for prominent linguists. There is no preset limit for the length of an article.
Some volumes are thematic. Vols. 10 (2005) and 11 (2006) were a two-volume edition dedicated to the 170th anniversary of [[August Pott]]'s seminal work, ''Etymologische Untersuchungen auf dem Gebiete der indo-germanischen Sprachen''. Vol. 13 (2008) was mostly dedicated to etymology of [[proper name]]s. Vol. 14 (2009) was ''in memoriam'' of the deceased member of the editorial staff, professor E. Helimski.
== External links == * {{Official|http://www2.filg.uj.edu.pl/ifo/kjasis/sec/}} * [http://www.ejournals.eu/SEC/ Ejournal site for full-text contents] * [http://www.wuj.pl/page,art,artid,181.html Journal page] at University website * [http://www.ceeol.com/aspx/publicationdetails.aspx?publicationid=09f709df-c3b2-4fcb-b525-7dc09fe5eee9 Journal page] at [[Central and Eastern European Online Library]]
